title: Federal Tax Brackets 2025
content:
Canadian Federal Income Tax Brackets for 2025:

- 15% on the first $55,867 of taxable income.
- 20.5% on the next $55,866 of taxable income (on the portion of taxable income over 55,867 up to $111,733).
- 26% on the next $61,942 of taxable income (on the portion of taxable income over $111,733 up to $173,205).
- 29% on the next $62,258 of taxable income (on the portion of taxable income over $173,205 up to $235,463).
- 33% of taxable income over $235,463.

Basic Personal Amount (BPA) for 2025 is $15,705 for individuals with net income of $173,205 or less.

title: Ontario Tax Brackets 2025
content:
Ontario Provincial Income Tax Brackets for 2025:

- 5.05% on the first $51,446 of taxable income.
- 9.15% on the next $51,446 (on the portion of taxable income over $51,446 up to $102,892).
- 11.16% on the next $57,144 (on the portion of taxable income over $102,892 up to $150,000).
- 12.16% on the next $70,000 (on the portion of taxable income over $150,000 up to $220,000).
- 13.16% on the portion of taxable income over $220,000.

Ontario Surtax: You may also pay surtax if your basic Ontario tax is over certain thresholds.

title: British Columbia Tax Brackets 2025
content:
British Columbia Provincial Income Tax Brackets for 2025:

- 5.06% on the first $47,937 of taxable income.
- 7.7% on the next $47,937 (over $47,937 up to $95,874).
- 10.5% on the next $12,045 (over $95,874 up to $107,919).
- 12.29% on the next $23,930 (over $107,919 up to $131,849).
- 14.7% on the next $47,860 (over $131,849 up to $179,709).
- 16.8% on the next $95,720 (over $179,709 up to $275,429).
- 20.5% on taxable income over $275,429.

title: Registered Retirement Savings Plan (RRSP) Rules
content:
Top 5 RRSP Rules:
1. Contribution Limit: 18% of your previous year's earned income, up to a maximum ($31,560 for 2024, max for 2025 is $32,490) plus unused contribution room from previous years.
2. Deadline: Contributions must be made within the first 60 days of the year (usually March 1st) to be deductible for the previous tax year.
3. Tax Deduction: Contributions reduce your taxable income dollar-for-dollar.
4. Over-contribution: Lifetime over-contribution buffer is $2,000. Going above this incurs a penalty of 1% per month.
5. Withdrawals: You can withdraw at any time, but it is taxed as income (unless HBP or LLP). Withholding tax applies immediately.

title: First Home Savings Account (FHSA)
content:
The First Home Savings Account (FHSA) allows prospective first-time home buyers to save for their first home tax-free.
- Contribution Limit: $8,000 per year, up to a $40,000 lifetime limit.
- Tax Deduction: Contributions are tax-deductible (like an RRSP).
- Tax-Free Growth: Investment income earned in the account is tax-free (like a TFSA).
- Tax-Free Withdrawal: Withdrawals used to buy a qualifying first home are non-taxable.
- Carry Forward: You can carry forward up to $8,000 of unused contribution room to the next year.

title: Tuition Tax Credit (T2202)
content:
Tuition fees paid to valid educational institutions can be claimed as a non-refundable tax credit.
- Form: T2202 (Tuition and Enrolment Certificate).
- Federal Credit: 15% of eligible tuition fees.
- Carry Forward: Unused credits can be carried forward indefinitely to future years.
- Transfer: Instead of carrying forward, you can transfer up to $5,000 of the *current year's* amount to a spouse, common-law partner, parent, or grandparent.

title: Moving Expenses Deduction
content:
You can claim moving expenses if:
1. You moved to be at least 40 kilometers closer to a new work location or post-secondary school.
2. You earned employment or self-employment income at the new location.

Eligible expenses include:
- Transportation and storage costs.
- Travel expenses (gas, meals, accommodation).
- Temporary living expenses (up to 15 days).
- Cost of cancelling a lease or selling your old home.
- Cost of purchasing a new home (if you sold your old one).

Claim on form T1-M.

title: Work From Home Expenses
content:
For 2023 onwards, the 'temporary flat rate method' ($2/day) is NO LONGER available. Employees must use the 'Detailed Method'.
Requirements:
- You worked from home more than 50% of the time for at least 4 consecutive weeks.
- Your employer required you to work from home (Form T2200 must be signed by employer).
- You can claim a portion of: electricity, heat, water, internet access fees, maintenance and repairs, and rent (but NOT mortgage interest or capital costs).
